title: What does flextension mean and what is the new Brexit date as EU confirms delay?
text:
The UK will be staying in the European Union until early 2020 after a fresh Brexit deal was agreed (Picture: Getty Images)

EU members have agreed to accept the UK’s request for a further Brexit delay, postponing the country’s departure from the European Union until January 2020.

Donald Tusk confirmed the news on Monday morning, after it was confirmed on Friday the EU27 would offer a further delay – without specifying how long this would be.

He also said that the new delay would be a ‘flextension’ – but what exactly does this mean and how will the new delay work?

Here’s what you need to know…

What is the new Brexit date?

The delay means that the UK is now set to leave the European Union on 31 January 2020.

Donald Tusk confirmed news of the latest delay on Twitter (Picture: AP)

It comes after Boris Johnson wrote to Mr Tusk to ask for an extension as demanded by the Benn Act – which was passed by MPs in September in order to avoid crashing out of the bloc with no deal.

Mr Tusk said in his tweet: ‘The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the UK’s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020. ‘The decision is expected to be formalised through a written procedure.’

What does ‘flextension’ mean?

Boris Johnson is now set to make his case for a general election before the end of the year (Picture: Getty Images)

‘Flextension’ means that while the UK has until 31 January 2020 to leave the EU, the country could leave sooner than that if a deal is ratified.

If Boris Johnson’s deal were to be approved by Parliament, the UK could then leave on the first day of the month after it has been passed.

The longer extension has been agreed despite reports that French president Emmanuel Macron was pushing for a shorter extension.

It also paves the way for a potential general election, with Boris Johnson set to ask MPs on Monday to back his call for the public to go to the polls on 12 December.

Will there be a general election and if so when?

Jeremy Corbyn has indicated Labour would support an election if no-deal is taken off the table (Picture: PA)

The Prime Minister announced his election intentions after MPs voted against his timetable to rush through his Brexit deal in order for the UK to leave this Thursday, 31 October.

While his EU Withdrawal Bill was voted through last week, he lost a vote on a timetable to rush it through Parliament in time for this week’s proposed Brexit date.

In order to win support for a general election Mr Johnson will need the backing of two-thirds of MPs – 434 – to succeed under the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act (FTPA).

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has previously indicated the party will only support a general election if the possibility of a no-deal Brexit is taken ‘completely off the table’.

description: The EU has offered the UK a fresh delay to Brexit - this time offering a 'flextension', but what does the term mean?
